Package me.wobblyyyy.rlibx.manager

Class ModeExecutor

java.lang.Object
me.wobblyyyy.rlibx.manager.Mode
me.wobblyyyy.rlibx.manager.LinearMode
me.wobblyyyy.rlibx.manager.ModeExecutor
public class ModeExecutor
extends LinearMode
Manager class used in managing the execution of several different modes.

In reality, a ModeExecutor is an extension of the LinearMode class. When the ModeExecutor is created, all of the Mode elements that were passed to the executor's constructor will be started. Stopping them can be accomplished by calling the stop method. Re-starting them from there can be accomplished with the start method. It's suggested that you don't stop or start threads if you don't have to, as stopping and starting threads isn't exactly a suggested thing.

Since:
0.1.0
Author:
Colin Robertson

  • Field Details

    • modes

      private final java.util.ArrayList<Mode> modes
      An internally-used list of all of the Mode elements that should be stopped/started whenever trying to do either of those lovely things with this lovely code.

  • Constructor Details

    • ModeExecutor

      public ModeExecutor​(Mode mode)
      Create a new ModeExecutor based on a single inputted mode.

      None of these modes will begin execution until the start() method has been called. Until that point, the modes will simply sit dormant.

      If you'd like to stop the execution of a mode executor before it has reached its natural conclusion, you can use the stop() method to do exactly that.

      Parameters:
      mode - the mode that should be executed when this ModeExecutor has its functionality used.

    • ModeExecutor

      public ModeExecutor​(java.util.ArrayList<Mode> modes)
      Create a new ModeExecutor based on an ArrayList of modes that should be executed with the mode executor.

      None of these modes will begin execution until the start() method has been called. Until that point, the modes will simply sit dormant.

      If you'd like to stop the execution of a mode executor before it has reached its natural conclusion, you can use the stop() method to do exactly that.

      Parameters:
      modes - a list of all of the modes that should be executed when the mode executor's execution functionality is executed. Damn, that's a lot of execution.

  • Method Details

    • start

      public void start()
      Execute the Runnable.

      This starts the execution of all of the modes in the mode manager.

      Execution can't be started more than once - well, it can, but the issue you're going to then encounter is that the execution will restart, because the thread is initialized here.

      Overrides:
      start in class Mode

    • stop

      public void stop()
      Stop the runnable execution prematurely.

      This stops the execution of all of the modes in the mode manager.

      Stopping thread execution is generally discouraged and will 100% be deprecated soon.

      Overrides:
      stop in class Mode
